1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Marine Corps Base (MCB) Camp Pendleton is the United States Marine Corps? largest amphibious assault training facility. MCB Camp Pendleton covers an area of approximately 125,000 acres and is populated by over 40,000 military personnel and civilian employees in addition to numerous military dependents. MCB Camp Pendleton provides its own water supply and wastewater treatment facilities within its boundaries. Disinfection is therefore necessary to reduce the potential for transmission of infectious diseases. Chlorination has long been the accepted and preferred method of disinfection for both water and wastewater in the United States. The same properties that make chlorine valuable as a disinfectant also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human exposure during handling and to protect the health of persons on MCB Camp Pendleton and in the surrounding communities.

1.1    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Prevention of accidental releases for the MCB Camp Pendleton chlorine systems is dependent on developed chlorine handling procedures, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facilities, and staff training.  MCB Camp Pendleton facilities have been assessed against the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Standard 55 ? Storage, Use and Handling of Compressed and Liquefied Gases in Portable Cylinders, and it is Base policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. The buildings are clearly marked ?Danger Chlorine? to reduce unauthorized entry. Each chlorine system is enclosed in a locked building and access is restricted to authorized employees and contractors.

DENT HISTORY
CalARP regulations require facilities to compile a five-year accident history. This is defined as ?all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage? (California Code of Regulations [CCR], Title 19, Chapter 4.5, Section 2750.9). According to information provided by the Base Fire Department and AC/S, Env Scty, there have been no accidental releases from the Program Level 3 chlorine systems that meet the above definition since the original RMP was issued on 21 June 1999.

1.6    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Emergency Response Program is based upon the existing management system (see Appendix A) for responding to emergencies, the appropriate discovery and notification procedures, and coordination with the HIRT. The operators and maintenance staff from the Facilities Maintenance Department (FMD) have been trained as Facilities Responders to report accidental releases to the Base Fire Department.  The Base Fire Department subsequently notifies HIRT for emergency response actions if needed.  The AC/S, Env Scty plays an active role in notifying the appropriate government agencies and communicating releases to the public.
